PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name FREDERICK WILLIAM HUMPHREY
Address MELFORT SASK
Birthplace ST ALBANS ENGLAND

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? 5 miles N.W. of where Ridgeway now is
Where had you been living before that? England
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? 25 miles (Star City)
How often could a visit be made to the store? Went as seldom as possible. Sometimes 3 months.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, Rolled Oats, Sugar, Egg, Baking Powder, Lard, sometimes butter (hard ever part of time), Syrup, Beans (lots), Prunes and other dried fruit

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Molson's
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Cannot remember
How much did you use graham flour? Possibly 50%
Whole wheat flour? Never heard of it in the early days
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Cannot remember
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal? Yes Whole Wheat? No Farina? No Other? Rolled Oats
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Not until after marriage in 1921
How did you grind it? By the feed crusher
1906 Humphrey, Frederick William
Melfort.

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: FREDERICK WILLIAM HUMPHREY
Address: MELFORT, SASK.
Birthplace: ST. ALBANS, ENGLAND

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? 5 miles NW of Melfort, where Richard lives.
Have you been living there before that? Yes
For how many years have you lived there? 2 years
How far was it to your nearest store? 5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly
What groceries did you usually buy in those early years?
Flour, sugar, tea, coffee, salt, butter, cheese, canned goods, flour, sugar, tea, coffee, salt, butter, cheese, canned goods.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
McKee's Flour
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 44¢
How much did you use gristmill flour? 50%
Whole wheat flour? No
Was flour milled locally? No
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 3¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal, flour, whole wheat, other
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? By hand, using a millstone.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs. each, later 5 at a time.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? Cannot remember.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Ludwigsburg Table Syrup.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 2 lb.

At what price? Cannot remember.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Had a cow.

Butter? Purchased when no cows.

That was the price of butter? 15 to 25 cents per quart.

Did you pick eggs for winter? Not often.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Little fresh meat at first.

Later killed a steer or pig.

How did you get fresh meat? Purchased a little. Butchered some later.

How often did you get fresh meat? Very irregularly.

How did you preserve meat? None at first. Later in June.

Later still (after 1921) by dry curing.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not until many years later.

If so what year was it organized? Possibly 1922.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Pheasant, Mole, Deer, Ducks in summer, Rabbits in winter.

For how long? Possibly till 1922.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Small part.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned.

Kinds? Salmon, Pilchard, Sardine.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon at what price? $1.00
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Blue Ribbon beans
Price? $1.00. That other beverages were used? 

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from? 
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1912, Cabbage 1914, Carrots 1922, Onions 1922,
Turnips 1922, Beets 1922.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lb. lots
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box
What weight? 25 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes
What was the price of prunes? 
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drain? No
peas? corn? beans? Saskatoons? other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? After marriage in 1921
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? Same
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? Same

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes
By canning. We live in town now
To what extent? Try to have years supply
Did you make your own vinegar? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) Carrot River; small hole at side of slough.

How far was this water from your home? 3 miles.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Wells have been dug or bored. 4 more recently (possibly 1930) dug-outs.
We got the information that all four places

were off for our trip.

If you want to know more about the places we visited, please let me know.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Lived very economically.

Breakfast - porridge (rolled oats), bread & butter, occasional bacon.

Dinner - Potatoes, bread & butter, occasional meat.

Supper - Bread & butter, prunes, occasional eggs.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ......................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Not much festivities in those days.

All men were bachelors. There was great freedom and neighborliness among them.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Lived on a low level at times, largely bread & potatoes.

Everybody wanted to get on with the land clearing then rather than go out to work. Ours was scrub country, & we cleared with an axe, not with power machinery.
17. Give a typical day's menu (considerably lighter & simpler) for the earliest year you can remember. (Give only four and list the names of the family members.)

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Olive the menu. List cheese, canned goods as at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two mainstays? Bread & potatoes.

20. Land clearing then rather than go out to work. We cleared with an axe, not with power machinery.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Everything was fried then (meat, potatoes).
Great care was made of beans & dried fruit because they did not freeze. A trip to town took two days, & we had no proper storage.
Every man was alone, and everything freezeable froze while we were away. We had to empty out all water & freezeable things.

Would you call this "housekeeping"?

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Monthly, from the first.

Homegrown foods (vegetables) could not be kept, through lack of frost proof storage facilities.
That did not come till after marriage in 1921.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Coming from England where everything and best was at its cheapest, we thought quality was very poor, and prices relatively quite high.
We had no proper storage until after 1921, and some years I pitted some potatoes in an outside pit through the winter.
Was not aware of shortages, except during World War I. Sugar was the greatest shortage with us.
